content: How can I help you today?
I’ve been having a lot of trouble sleeping lately. There’s just so much on my mind, and I can’t seem to shut it off at night. My partner suggested I talk to someone, so here I am.

It's great that you’re open to exploring this and taking the step to talk about it. It sounds like your struggles with sleep and a busy mind have been weighing on you. Would you like to share more about what’s been on your mind or how this has been affecting you?

I think a lot of it has to do with work stress. I’m honestly worried about getting fired, especially with all the talk about layoffs. I feel like I can’t keep up, and it’s really affecting me—I can’t stop thinking about what might happen if I lose my job.

That sounds incredibly stressful, and it seems like the uncertainty around work is creating a lot of anxiety for you. It takes courage to share these feelings. How have you been handling this pressure, and what impact has it had on your daily life?

I haven’t been handling it well, to be honest. Most nights, my thoughts just race, and I end up lying awake for hours. I’ll grab my phone to distract myself, but then I get caught up in news or social media, and it just feeds into the stress. It’s been making me feel exhausted and even more on edge during the day.

Facing sleepless nights and racing thoughts sounds overwhelming, especially when it's leaving you feeling drained during the day. It sounds like you’re trying to find ways to cope, but some of the things you turn to, like your phone, might be adding to your stress. What matters most to you when it comes to managing this and finding some relief?
I just want to feel like I’m in control again, like I can actually rest and wake up with the energy to handle work and be there for my family. Right now, I just feel stuck in this cycle.

Wanting to regain control and feel more energized to face both work and family is such an important goal. Feeling stuck, especially with everything you’re juggling, can be really tough. What do you think might help you start breaking out of this cycle, even if it’s just a small step?

I'm not sure where to start, but I think cutting back on grabbing my phone at night might help. It's just so hard because it feels like the only distraction I have. I don't really know what else to do.

That's a thoughtful insight—you recognize how reaching for your phone adds to the cycle but also gives you a momentary distraction. Taking steps to reduce that habit could make a difference, even if it’s challenging at first. What might be another way for you to unwind or calm your mind at night that feels doable?

Maybe I could try reading a book or listening to some calming music instead. It feels like it might help, but honestly, I’m not sure if it’ll work—I’ve been so wound up that nothing seems to quiet my thoughts.

It’s understandable to feel uncertain about new approaches, especially when you’ve been feeling so caught up in stress. Exploring activities like reading or calming music sounds like a step worth trying, and it’s encouraging that you’re thinking about alternatives. What could make it easier to give these options a chance and see how they feel?

Maybe I could set a limit for myself—like putting my phone away at a certain time and having a book or playlist ready to go instead. That way, I’m not scrambling to figure out what to do in the moment. It feels hard, but maybe having a plan would help.

That sounds like a thoughtful and practical idea. Setting a limit and preparing ahead could help you feel more in control of your bedtime routine. It’s great that you’re already thinking about ways to make this manageable. What would help you stay motivated to stick with this plan, even during those tougher nights?

I think reminding myself why I’m doing this would help—like thinking about how better sleep could make me a better parent, partner, and worker. It’s not easy to stay motivated when I’m so stressed, but keeping those reasons in mind might keep me going, even if it’s just a small improvement at first.

That’s a powerful motivation—connecting this change to the things and people you care about most could really help you stay focused, even during challenging times. It sounds like you’re ready to take some steps toward improving your sleep. Before moving forward, is there anything else you’d like to talk about or reflect on regarding how stress has been affecting your life recently?
I think I’ve said everything for now. Thank you for taking the time to talk through this with me—it’s given me some things to think about and try. I’ll see how it goes.
